fr:title.text: {Y} = {p(e)}{{H}_{ n }} is a feasible dual solution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \hat {y} = \frac {p(e)}{\mathcal {H}_{ n }} is a feasible dual solution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We only need to show that the constraint \sum _{ e \in S } y_{ e } \geq c_{ S } \quad \forall S \in \mathcal {S} is satisfied, as by definition, y_{ e } \geq 0 . We start by ordering the elements \{ e_1, \ldots , e_k \} as they are covered. We claim that p(e_{ i }) \leq \frac {c(S)}{k-i+1} .

We show why p(e_{ i }) \leq \frac {c(S)}{k-i+1} . Let S' be the set used to cover e_{ i } . Therefore, S' must be minimal cost set that the algorithm found to cover e_{ i } . Before adding S' to \mathcal {C} , e_{ i }, \ldots , e_{ k } were uncovered. By defintion, if S were some set that covered e_{ i } , then the cost of covering e_{ i } would be: \frac {c(S)}{k-i+1} where the +1 is because we haven't added e_{ i } yet. Since S' is the minimal cost set it follows that: c(S') \leq \frac {c(S)}{k-i+1}

fr:title.text: If all sets in {S} have size at most k , then the greedy set cover algorithm finds an O( k)-approximation of an optimal set cover

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: If all sets in \mathcal {S} have size at most k , then the greedy set cover algorithm finds an O(\lg k)-approximation of an optimal set cover

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The proof follows immediately from Lemma by substituting \mathcal {H}_{ k } instead of \mathcal {H}_{ n } , and both numerator and denominator cancel out to give 1 .
